title: Week 6: Data Gathering
text:
Goals


What types of data can you gather?
What sources can data come from?
How is data stored (for CMPSC 105)?

title: Week 6: Data Gathering
text:
Data Types


and numerical discrete!

title: Week 6: Data Gathering
text:
Categorical Nominal


Name only, qualitative

car makes
zip code
eye color

Dichotomous variable refers to a categorical nominal variables with only two values

left handed / right handed
current student / non student

title: Week 6: Data Gathering
text:
Categorical Ordinal


ordered, quasi-quantitative

agreement level
education level

ordinal data can seem almost quantitative, but there is no way to know the value of the levels
ordinal scales are usually used to measure non-numeric features like happiness, customer satisfaction
Likert Items are often used to obtain categorical ordinal data

title: Week 6: Data Gathering
text: Likert Items

title: Week 6: Data Gathering
text:
Numerical Data


Numerical data are quantitative
Discrete means countable

number of students
number of views or likes

title: Week 6: Data Gathering
text:
Numerical Data


Numerical data are quantitative
Continuous means measured

height must be measured
Interval refers to continuous data with no reference point

temperature, we know 28 F vs 33 F is a difference of 5, but does a difference of 5 mean the same thing between 100 and 105?
Interval data cannot be divided meaningfully. Don’t compute what is 1/5 of the temperature today
Stats use division, causing a problem for interval data

Ratio refers to continuous data with a reference point

Height, weight, distance, speed
division or other ratios are meaningful. Professor Luman is twice my height!

title: Week 6: Data Gathering
text:
Practice
Recall an example for each data type


and numerical discrete!

https://forms.gle/rqqcmMtnEHc6g3276

title: Week 6: Data Gathering
text:
Data Acquisition
Getting brand new data using surveys and sensors!

title: Week 6: Data Gathering
text:
Surveys for Acquisition


surveys are directed toward people
surveys answer subjective perceptual and behavioral questions, primarily
different questions produce different data types

multiple choice questions
free response questions
slider ratings
Likert scales

title: Week 6: Data Gathering
text:
Surveys for Acquisition


Survey development should be guided by a hypothesis
Only questions that have appropriate data types for analysis should be used
Quality controls should be in place (e.g. timestamps, inclusion criteria)
Data security protocols should be in place to protect private data
Human Subjects Research must be reviewed by the Institutional Review Board



Reading: Surveys

title: Week 6: Data Gathering
text:
Sensors for Acquisition


sensors can measure inanimate objects/materials or people/animals
electronic sensors for things

motion detection
freezer thermometer
tire pressure sensor

sensors for people

motion capture
body temperature
electro-physiological

ECG - electrocardiogram
EEG - electroencephalogram
electrodermal

title: Week 6: Data Gathering
text: Sensors for Acquisition

title: Week 6: Data Gathering
text:
Acquisition Drawbacks


time consuming
data management is required (persistent storage, security)
maybe the data already exist somewhere
maybe surveys and sensors cannot answer the question you have

title: Week 6: Data Gathering
text:
Extracting Data from Documents


Documents often contain information but it is not in an analyzable format

Author names on research papers
Foreground of an image
Background of an image
Video transcripts of speech
Video transcripts of sounds
Cells (biology) appearing in images
Language structure

noun, verb, adj, conjunction,
word length
num vowels
num syllables
etc

title: Week 6: Data Gathering
text:
Extracting Data by Web Scraping


Scraping is gathering data form websites by reading into the html structure to get the content out of specific html tagged elements.
Scraping tools exist to assist with formatting

Requests, BeautifulSoup, Selenium
example with https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tadasu_no_Mori





import requests
# Making a GET request
r = requests.get('https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tadasu_no_Mori')
# print content of request
print(r.content)

title: Week 6: Data Gathering
Week 6: Data Gathering
text:
Extracting Data Storage


extracted data must be entered into usable structures

databases
spreadsheets
plain text files

title: Week 6: Data Gathering
text:
Drawbacks of Extracting Data


data entry is time consuming
data should be consistent, but real data is never perfect, so compromises must be made
human errors can be difficult to detect
data entry done with automated entry tools is hard to validate
validation takes human time, or accepted inaccuracy

title: Week 6: Data Gathering
text:
Sources of Pre-existing Data


Tableau Data
Others

title: Week 6: Data Gathering
text:
Drawbacks of Pre-existing Data


Ethical collection practices may or may not have been used
data have been used repeatedly in explorations leading to bias and overfitting on the data across explorations
maybe the pre-existing data cannot answer the question you have

title: Class Activity
text:
Variables and Assignment (REF)


Code
# Variables are names - a reusable label for a data value.

name = 'Marc'
print(name)
pi = 3.14
print(pi)
customer_id = "1234"
# TODO: add a print statement to see customer_id
account_balance = 1000
# TODO: add a print statement to see account_balance




Code
# if the same name is used to store new data, the old data is lost

pi = 3.14
print(pi)
pi = 'Marc'
# TODO: add a print statement to see pi




Code
# assignment is a fancy term for associating or storing data

# here 3.14 is assigned to the variable name pi using the `=`
pi = 3.14

# TODO: assign the value 5 to pi
# TODO: add a print statement to see pi
# TODO: assign the value "hello" to message
# TODO: add a print statement to see message
# TODO: assign the value [1,2,3,4,5] to data
# TODO: add a print statement to see data



Reserved Words
The following words have special meaning in Python. We call them keywords or reserved words and you may not use these names for your program variables.

and, as, assert, async, await, break, class, continue, def, del, elif, else, except, False, finally, for, from, global, if, import, in, is, lambda, nonlocal, None, not, or, pass, raise, return, True, try, while, with, yield

title: Class Activity
text:
Matrix


Code
# TODO: run this code to make a simple matrix in a pandas dataframe

import pandas as pd

matrix = pd.read_csv(
    '/content/data-filtering-matrix.csv',
    sep=',',
    names = ['A', 'B', 'C'],
    skiprows=1)




Code
# TODO: add a print statement to see the dataframe
print(matrix)




Code
# The matrix contains 15 values in five rows and three columns
# TODO: verify this using the data explorer


# Each item has a unique location in the matrix given by its row and column
# Using python convention, the rows and columns are idenfied with integers starting at 0!

# On the 0th row, column 0 has the value of 0.0
# On the 4nd row, column 0 has the value of 4.0
# TODO: What is the largest row index in the matrix?
# TODO: What is the largest column index in the matrix?

# Here's how you access the element on row 4, column 0
element = matrix.iloc[4,0]
print(element)

# TODO: access the element on row 3 column 2 and assign it to the variable `another_element`
# TODO: add a print statement to see `another_element`

# TODO: make sure you get what you expect!




Code
# Indexing to get one element is very simple, but what if you want multiple elements in a row, or in a column?

# Slicing is the way to do it!
# the sytax for slicing is like this: [start_index:end_index:hop_size]
# Using python convention, note that the end_index will not be included in the slice

# Here is a slice example on the columns
slice_example = matrix.iloc[0,0:2:1]
print(slice_example)

# TODO: use words to write out what the slice contains

# TODO: Write a slice that gets the first through fourth rows (not including 4) from column two and assign it to a variable
# TODO: add a print statement to see your slice

# TODO: Write a slice that gets the 0th through fourth rows (not including 4) from column one, hopping by 2, and assign it to a variable
# TODO: add a print statement to see your slice

# TODO: Come up with your own example

# TODO: make sure you get what you expect!




Code
# The syntax of a slice is [start:end:hop_size], but if start or end is left out, then the endpoints are assumed!
# warning - don't forget to include the `:`

# Here is every columns in row 0, including the start and INCLUDING the end!
full_slice = matrix.iloc[0,::1]
print(full_slice)

# TODO: Write a slice that gets every column in row 4, including the start and INCLUDING the end! Assign to a variable
# TODO: add a print statement to see your slice

# TODO: make sure you get what you expect! Is there anything unexpected?




Code
# Slices to endpoints have already been used in our labs

# TODO: find any spot where the slices have been used in our labs and put a link for yourself below
# TODO: how was the slice used in the lab?

title: Class Activity
text:
Logical Control


Code
# First lets review some comparison operators


The following table summarizes the most commonly used comparison operators in Python, along with their definition when applied to numbers.



operator
operation on numbers




==
equal to


!=
not equal to


>
greater than


>=
greater than or equal to


<
less than


<=
less than or equal to



As their name suggests, comparison operators allow us to compare two values.


Code
# Here is a comparison of 4 vs 5. It asks the question: is four larger than five?
# TODO: what answer should come out?
# TODO: run this, what does come out?
4 > 5




Code
# As you can see, comparison operators allow us to compare values and result in a boolean type indicating whether the comparison is `True` or `False`.
# TODO: make a comparison the checks if five is greater than four, assign to a variable and print it
# TODO: make a comparison the checks if five is not equal to four, assign to a variable and print it
# TODO: make a comparison the checks if five is equal to four, assign to a variable and print it




Code
# TODO: what is the difference between `=` and `==`?




Code
# It turns out that matrices can be compared too!
# What elements in the matrix are greater than 1?

# TODO: what do you think will happen
selection = matrix > 1
# TODO: add a print statement to see selection
# Does it match your expectations?




Code
# Write another comparison with matrix to ask which elements are equal to 4, assign to a variable called select_4 and print




Code
# Now we can use the selection to access only those elements!
# The rows and columns do not need to be set.
# Simply use the selection as the only index! Amazing!

result = matrix[selection]
print(result)

# TODO: use select_4 as the only index, assign to variable and print
# TODO: Does it match your expectations?




Code
# Finally, I want to show you how to combine comparions
# Think of this question: what elements in the matrix are greater than one AND less then three?
# The AND is done with `&`

greaterthanone = matrix > 1
print("greather than one: \n", greaterthanone)
lessthanthree = matrix < 3
print("less than three: \n", lessthanthree)
both = greaterthanone & lessthanthree
print("both: \n", both)
result = matrix[both]
print("result: \n", result)

# TODO: Does it match your expectations?




Code
# Here is the same thing, but all in one line of code...

print(matrix[(matrix > 1) & (matrix < 3)])




Code
# TODO: think of one or more questions you have and then post it in discord.
# TODO: As you see your colleagues questions, reply to their message if you have the answer!

title: Class Activity
text:
Dataframe Control with .loc


Code
# Controlling a Dataframe is similar to controlling a matrix.
# Slicing is possible and logical comparison are possible!
# One of the main differences is that indexing is done with .loc

# Below is a the hourly temperature normals dataset for Meadville in a pandas dataframe called `dfm`
# This same dataset was used in the data_distortion lab
# The columns are named
# The column containing the normals is called `HLY-TEMP-NORMAL`
# Each hour is a year is given in the column called `INDEX`
# A readable label for each hour in a year is given in the column called `DATE`

# lets apply your new skills of logical indexing to this dataset




Code
# TODO: run this cell

# load pre-existing tools available for data exploration
import pandas as pd
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt

# create a pandas dataframe
dfm = pd.read_csv(
    'https://raw.githubusercontent.com/allegheny-college-cmpsc-105-spring-2025/data-distortion-starter/refs/heads/main/data/data-distortion-noaa-2006-2020-USW00004843.csv',
    sep=',',
    names = ['INDEX', 'STATION', 'NAME', 'LATITUDE', 'LONGITUDE', 'ELEVATION',
       'DATE', 'month', 'day', 'hour', 'HLY-TEMP-NORMAL'],
    skiprows=1
)

# Display the first few rows of the DataFrame
print(dfm.head())




Code
# TODO: how many rows are in the dataframe?
# TODO: how many columns are in the dataframe?




Code
# This cell creates logical filters, then applies them with .loc

# Only rows from the midnight hour in the month of March are selected
selected_hours = dfm['hour'] == 0
selected_months = dfm['month'] == 3
selected_rows = selected_hours & selected_months


# new dataframes are made that contain ONLY THE SELECTED ROWS using .loc
# here is the syntax for .loc: .loc[rows, columns]
dfm_selected_normals = dfm.loc[selected_rows, 'HLY-TEMP-NORMAL']
dfm_selected_indices = dfm.loc[selected_rows, 'INDEX']
dfm_selected_dates = dfm.loc[selected_rows, 'DATE']


print(dfm_selected_normals)
print(dfm_selected_indices)
print(dfm_selected_dates)




Code
# Here is the same thing in one line

dfm.loc[(dfm['hour'] == 0) & (dfm['month'] == 3), 'INDEX']




Code
# Assuming df is already created in the previous code cell

# TODO: Run this code cell
# TODO: What does the figure show?
# TODO: Fill in appropriate title, xlabel and ylabel using you understanding of logical indexing

# Control how many xtick labels are on the x axis
xtick_hopsize = 3

# Clear out memory (doesn't impact the visualization, but keeps the computer happy)
plt.close('all')

# make a blank canvas
plt.figure(figsize=(12, 4))

# set the overall title for all subfigures
plt.suptitle('Figure 1')

# subplot 1
plt.subplot(1, 2, 1)
plt.plot(dfm.loc[(dfm['hour'] == 7) & (dfm['month'] == 2), 'INDEX'], dfm.loc[(dfm['hour'] == 7) & (dfm['month'] == 2), 'HLY-TEMP-NORMAL'], '*-') # layer 1
plt.plot(dfm.loc[(dfm['hour'] == 8) & (dfm['month'] == 2), 'INDEX'], dfm.loc[(dfm['hour'] == 8) & (dfm['month'] == 2), 'HLY-TEMP-NORMAL'], '*-') # layer 2
plt.plot(dfm.loc[(dfm['hour'] == 9) & (dfm['month'] == 2), 'INDEX'], dfm.loc[(dfm['hour'] == 9) & (dfm['month'] == 2), 'HLY-TEMP-NORMAL'], '*-') # layer 3
plt.plot(dfm.loc[(dfm['hour'] == 10) & (dfm['month'] == 2), 'INDEX'], dfm.loc[(dfm['hour'] == 10) & (dfm['month'] == 2), 'HLY-TEMP-NORMAL'], '*-') # layer 4
plt.plot(dfm.loc[(dfm['hour'] == 11) & (dfm['month'] == 2), 'INDEX'], dfm.loc[(dfm['hour'] == 11) & (dfm['month'] == 2), 'HLY-TEMP-NORMAL'], '*-') # layer 5
plt.plot(dfm.loc[(dfm['hour'] == 12) & (dfm['month'] == 2), 'INDEX'], dfm.loc[(dfm['hour'] == 12) & (dfm['month'] == 2), 'HLY-TEMP-NORMAL'], '*-') # layer 6
plt.plot(dfm.loc[(dfm['hour'] == 13) & (dfm['month'] == 2), 'INDEX'], dfm.loc[(dfm['hour'] == 13) & (dfm['month'] == 2), 'HLY-TEMP-NORMAL'], '*-') # layer 7
plt.plot(dfm.loc[(dfm['hour'] == 14) & (dfm['month'] == 2), 'INDEX'], dfm.loc[(dfm['hour'] == 14) & (dfm['month'] == 2), 'HLY-TEMP-NORMAL'], '*-') # layer 8
plt.legend(['7 AM', '8 AM', '9 AM', '10 AM', '11 AM', '12 PM', '1 PM', '2 PM'])
# the plt.xticks function labels the ticks so that dates appear instead of index
plt.xticks(dfm.loc[(dfm['hour'] == 11) & (dfm['month'] == 2), 'INDEX'][::xtick_hopsize], dfm.loc[(dfm['hour'] == 11) & (dfm['month'] == 2), 'DATE'][::xtick_hopsize], rotation=90)
plt.xlabel('')
plt.ylabel('')
plt.title('')
plt.grid(True)

plt.show()

title: Syllabus: CMPSC 105.00 Data Exploration, Spring 2025
text:
Class Sessions: TuTh 9:30 AM-10:45 AM, Alden 101
Laboratory Session: Th, 2:30 PM-4 PM, Alden 101
Instructor: Professor Emily Graber, egraber@allegheny.edu
Office Location: Alden Hall 106
Office Hours: Visit Google Calendar to reserve an appointment as needed.

title: Syllabus: CMPSC 105.00 Data Exploration, Spring 2025
text:
Course Description
An introduction to the methods of collecting, exploring, transforming and visualizing data for storytelling. Often participating in team-based and hands-on activities, students learn how to use web platforms and dashboards to acquire, explore and investigate data to generate summarized key data insights using visual techniques. Students also apply open-source programming language to discover patterns in the data, test hypotheses, and check assumptions using graphical representations. During a weekly laboratory session, students employ cutting-edge software tools to complete projects, reporting on their results through both written documents and oral presentations. Students are invited to use their own departmentally approved laptop in this course; a limited number of laptops are available for use during class and lab sessions.
Prerequisite: None
Distribution Requirements: QR, SP.
DR tag rationale: This course will primarily focus on methods of data collection, foundational data analysis of numerical data, and visualizations of such data. Additionally, students will participate in the scientific process during the exploratory data analysis and apply scientific reasoning to analyze and synthesize data.

Learning Outcomes

Develop hypotheses based on motivating problems and/or observations and identify appropriate data to address hypotheses.
Identify and describe key elements in different types of data visualizations.
Use web-based platforms to accurately present data sets through multiple visualizations.
Use an open-source programming language to compute summary statistics and visualize key patterns in the data.
Contribute to and present structured, web-based documentation that describes data exploration steps and visualization-based conclusions.



Scientific Process and Knowledge (SP)

Courses involving Scientific Process and Knowledge aim to convey an understanding of what is known or can be known about the natural world; apply scientific reasoning towards the analysis and synthesis of scientific information; and create scientifically literate citizens who can engage productively in problem solving.
Learning Outcome: Students who successfully complete this requirement will demonstrate an understanding of the nature, approaches, and domain of scientific inquiry.



Quantitative Reasoning (QR)

Quantitative Reasoning is the ability to understand, investigate, communicate, and contextualize numerical, symbolic, and graphical information towards the exploration of natural, physical, behavioral, or social phenomena.
Learning Outcome: Students who successfully complete this requirement will demonstrate an understanding of how to interpret numeric data and/or their graphical or symbolic representations.

title: Syllabus: CMPSC 105.00 Data Exploration, Spring 2025
text:
Schedule at-a-glance
Welcome

Week One: January 14, 16: Setup

Data Display

Week Two: January 21, 23: Display Types and Anatomy of a Chart
Week Three: January 28, 30: Data Distortion
Week Four: February 4, 7: Data Filtering
Week Five: February 11, 13: Interactive Display

Data Gathering

Week Six: February 18, 20: Turning Anything Into Data 
Week Seven: February 25, 27: Web Data Analytics and Scraping
Spring Break: March 1-9
Week Eight: March 11, 13: Data Entry and Storage with Pandas

Data Processing

Week Nine: March 18, 20: Statistics
Week Ten: March 25, 27: Data Transformations
Week Eleven: April 1, 3: Modeling and Overfitting
Week Twelve: April 8: Clustering

Data Storytelling

Week Thirteen: April 15, 17: Hypothesis Driven Analysis
Week Fourteen: April 22, 24: Storytelling Challenge & Project Preparation
Week Fifteen: April 29: No Class Meeting

Final Presentations Code C

Thursday, May 1st, 2025 at 7:00 PM: Final Project Lightning Talks

Complete Final Exam Schedule

title: Syllabus: CMPSC 105.00 Data Exploration, Spring 2025
text:
Grading



Assignment type
Percentage




Labs
50%


Participation
30%


Final Project
20%



Grading policy may change as needed during the term; any changes will be announced to the class at the time of the change. Grades will be communicated via Canvas. Please note that attendance policies may additionally affect grades as adjustments to grades will be applied on top of the base grade according to policy

Labs
There are 8 labs during the semester. Due dates are hard deadlines. See below for policy on late work.
The deliverables for labs include documentation in a GitHub repo addressing specific questions or demonstrating requested calculations, analyses, visualizations, and code snippets.
Labs will be graded for having clean work with few careless errors, correct Markdown, code, data, correct images given the context of the lab, and correct explanations of concepts in writing


Participation
Participation in class work, group activities, and Discord are required. Documentation of in-class participation must be submitted by each student and cannot be made up. Participation on the Discord server can occur throughout each week. Each student is required to post at least once per week by asking either asking a real question or answering a question asked by your classmate. Collegial conversations about course topics or activities are also allowed.
You will have access to a repository for submitting all of your class activities. Each activity that you do in class will contribute to your overall participation grade. There is no grading scheme for class activities. I will simply check that the activity was turned in at the end of the class period, and that you have made an effort to do the activity as intended, and figures are showing.
If the activity is not turned in at the end of the class period, then it will not be counted toward your participation grade.


Final Project
The final project will be open ended. Techniques and skills learned throughout the course should be demonstrated in the project in a final presentation (included in the final project grade). The project must be approved by the teaching team in an initial stage. The artifact can be detailed blog post, following the format of the last lab, or a detailed data visualization with interactive visuals.

title: Syllabus: CMPSC 105.00 Data Exploration, Spring 2025
text:
Policies

Attendance
Students are expected to come to class prepared, on time, and to stay engaged for the duration of the class period. This includes both class and lab sessions. This behavior is core to our shared departmental values and is in addition to the college’s attendance policy.

Preparedness
Coming to class prepared means coming with everything you need to engage in a class session. To satisfy basic expectations of CIS courses, this means, at minimum, that students must:

arrive at class with a fully charged laptop
bring their laptop charger or a battery pack so as to ensure that their laptop works throughout the entire class session
complete any pre-session work such as readings and preparatory assignments



Attendance and Lateness
One missed class or lab session counts as one absence. Coming to class/lab late, leaving early, or missing a large portion of a class/lab session will result in your being marked as “late” to class. Coming to class/lab unprepared may also result in being marked “late”. Being marked “late” to class three times during the course of a semester is equal to one absence.
Students can have five absences without any impact to their grade. These accommodations are meant to cover illness and emergency, so you should always come to class if you are able to do so.
As a general guideline, students cannot miss more than two weeks of class in total throughout the academic semester without receiving a letter grade reduction.
For this course, excluding the first week and five excused absences, overall course grade will go down by 1/3 of a letter grade for each additional absence or absence equivalence regardless of base grade.


Engagement
The term “engagement” or our expectation that students remain “engaged” can mean many things, often varying by course. Baseline behaviors that indicate engagement include:

participation in class activities and discussions
defined contribution to class sessions in full-class or group discussions
note-taking (physical or digital)
participating in course session attendance requirements
not participating in non-course related activities
not completing non-course related projects




Late Work Policy
The deadlines for assignments are hard deadlines. This policy is intended to ensure that students keep up with course topics, are able to actively participate in class, and are accountable for managing time effectively.
All students in the CIS department are expected to turn in assignments on time. “On time” means on or before the assignment’s due date. This means that an assignment cannot be turned in for credit after a due date, unless the student applies a token.

Tokens
Students in 105 are allotted four tokens to receive extensions on any assignment except the final with no questions asked by the course instructor except either in the rare cases of documented severe and/or extenuating circumstances or in cases that violate the CIS policy document or any College-approved policy.
A token may be applied via a Google Form up to the assignment deadline, with exceptions granted only for severe and/or extenuating circumstances.
Tokens grant an automatic extension of one week to anything except the final exam.
Token Form for Automatic Extension



Extenuating Circumstances
Extenuating circumstances are exceptional, unforeseen, outside of your control, and short-term, like illness and emergency. Regular circumstances associated with taking courses at Allegheny College are not considered extenuating.
The accommodations provided by tokens and permitted absences are meant to cover extenuating circumstances like illness, emergency, and work. However, if you have a contagious illness like COVID-19, the flu, or a cold, you should not come to class. If you have expended all your absences and tokens and are still sick with a contagious illness, you may contact your professor about options. If your symptoms are mild or you are recovering from a respiratory illness, we recommend that you wear a mask to class.
Professor must be informed of all athletic obligations at the beginning of the semester, or with as much notice as possible. If you are feeling healthy and well, you should make every effort to come to class on time and to complete assignments, rather than using absences and tokens you may need later.
These no-questions-asked accommodations are meant to protect student privacy, and to remove the additional effort of acquiring documentation under duress of illness or emergency. In addition, they allow the professor to remain focused on teaching rather than adjudicating excuses.
If extenuating circumstances are severe enough to require more absences and tokens, you may contact your professor to discuss options. In most cases, however, a situation of this gravity warrants a request for a “Late Drop” or “Incomplete” in the course, as the student will not have had adequate opportunity to learn the material.

title: Syllabus: CMPSC 105.00 Data Exploration, Spring 2025
text:
Communications

Using GitHub and Discord
This course will primarily use GitHub and Discord for collaborative course communication. Communications that are not private matters must take place in the Data Exploration Channel in Discord.
The Allegheny College Computer and Information Science Discord Server will also have useful announcements about departmental activities including TL office hours.


Using Email
Although we will primarily use Discord for class communication, the course instructor will sometimes use email to send announcements about important matters such as changes in the schedule. It is your responsibility to check your email at least once a day and to ensure that you can reliably send and receive emails.

title: Syllabus: CMPSC 105.00 Data Exploration, Spring 2025
text:
Honor Code
The Academic Honor Program that governs the entire academic program at Allegheny College is described in the Allegheny Academic Bulletin. The Honor Program applies to all work that is submitted for academic credit or to meet non-credit requirements for graduation at Allegheny College. This includes all work assigned for this class (e.g., examinations and course assignments). All students who have enrolled in the College will work under the Honor Program. Each student who has matriculated at the College has acknowledged the following Honor Code pledge:

I hereby recognize and pledge to fulfill my responsibilities, as defined in the Honor Code, and to maintain the integrity of both myself and the College community as a whole.


Effective Collaboration
Computer science is an inherently collaborative discipline. The Department of Computer and Information Science at Allegheny College encourages students to engage in collaboration. However, in the context of individual coursework, through which each student must demonstrate their own knowledge, there are certain forms of collaboration that are and are not acceptable.

Acceptable forms of collaboration include:

Discussing high-level concepts.
Referring someone to a course text book, course slides, example programs, or other resources that contain helpful information or instructions.
Outlining the high-level steps to solving a problem, without mentioning specific
lines of code that need to be written.

Unacceptable forms of collaboration include:

Sharing details about specific lines of code, including showing your source code to someone or looking at someone else’s code.
Copying someone else’s source code, technical writing, program commands, or program output, even with some slight modifications.
Typing source code, technical writing, or commands on someone else’s computer.




Plagiarism and Artificial Intelligence
Students may not pass off or represent the work of another student, or their own prior work, as their own current work in any case. Plagiarism and AI-generatated code, text, or images are not permitted in any assignment type unless the instructions supplied for the assignment explicitly state otherwise.For exams and all other coursework, students are expected to adhere to the given instructions for the particular exam or item of coursework. It is the responsibility of the student to review the authorization specifications on every item and act appropriately, upholding the honor code. Suspected plagiarized or unauthorized use of AI to generate the work that is turned in will be reported to the Honor Code Committee. This policy does not preclude the use of AI to learn.

title: Syllabus: CMPSC 105.00 Data Exploration, Spring 2025
text:
Educational Accommodations
The Americans with Disabilities Act (ADA) is a federal anti-discrimination statute that provides comprehensive civil rights protection for persons with disabilities. Among other things, this legislation requires all students with disabilities be guaranteed a learning environment that provides for reasonable accommodation of their disabilities. Students with disabilities who believe they may need accommodations in this class are encouraged to contact Student Accessibility and Support Services (SASS) at 814-332-2898. Student Accessibility and Support Services is part of the Learning Commons and is located in Pelletier Library. Please do this as soon as possible to ensure that approved accommodations are implemented in a timely fashion.

title: Interactive Data Display Activity
text:
More interesting function


Code
# Create a sine wave with frequency 2 Hz and amplitude 3. Use variable name y
# Then plot it

freq = 2
amplitude = 3

pi = 3.14159

t = np.arange(0, 2, 2/1000)
y = amplitude * np.sin(2 * pi * freq * t)


plt.figure(figsize=(8, 4))
plt.plot(t, y, label=f'Sin(2 pi {freq} t) * {amplitude}')
plt.xlabel('Time (seconds)')
plt.ylabel('Amplitude')
plt.legend()
plt.xlim(0,2)
plt.ylim(-5,5)
plt.grid(True)
plt.show()

# TODO: What happens when you run this code cell?




Code
def plot_sine(freq, amplitude):

  pi = 3.14159

  t = np.arange(0, 2, 2/1000)
  y = amplitude * np.sin(2 * pi * freq * t)


  plt.figure(figsize=(8, 4))
  plt.plot(t, y, label=f'Sin(2 pi {freq} t) * {amplitude}')
  plt.xlabel('Time (seconds)')
  plt.ylabel('Amplitude')
  plt.legend()
  plt.xlim(0,2)
  plt.ylim(-5,5)
  plt.grid(True)
  plt.show()

# TODO: What happens when you run this code cell?
# Decribe what you see above that is new




Code
plt.close('all')

plot_sine(freq=2, amplitude=3)

# TODO: What happens when you run this code cell?

plot_sine(freq=2, amplitude=1)

# TODO: What happens when you run this code cell?

Code


df = pd.read_csv(
    'https://raw.githubusercontent.com/allegheny-college-cmpsc-105-spring-2025/data-distortion-starter/refs/heads/main/data/data-distortion-noaa-2006-2020-USW00004843.csv',
    sep=',',
    names = ['INDEX', 'STATION', 'NAME', 'LATITUDE', 'LONGITUDE', 'ELEVATION',
       'DATE', 'month', 'day', 'hour', 'HLY-TEMP-NORMAL'],
    skiprows=1
)

print(df.head()) # Display the first few rows of the DataFrame




Code
# a plotting function
# it has a parameter called month

def plot_df(month):

    plt.figure(figsize=(8, 4))
    plt.plot(df.loc[df['month']==month,'INDEX'], df.loc[df['month']==month,'HLY-TEMP-NORMAL'])
    plt.xticks(df.loc[df['month']==month,'INDEX'][::72], df.loc[df['month']==month,'DATE'][::72], rotation=90)
    plt.xlabel('Time (hours)')
    plt.ylabel('Normals (F)')
    plt.title(f'Month {month}')
    plt.ylim(-20,100)
    plt.show()

# TODO: What happens when you run this cell?




Code
plt.close('all')


# The interact function takes the plotting function, and parameters of the plotting function!
# The parameters of the plotting function turn into sliders
# the slider must be specified with some information: (start, end, hop)


interact(plot_df, month=(1,12,1))

title: Syllabus: CMPSC 105.00 Data Exploration, Spring 2025
text:
Class Sessions: TuTh 9:30 AM-10:45 AM, Alden 101
Laboratory Session: Th, 2:30 PM-4 PM, Alden 101
Instructor: Professor Emily Graber, egraber@allegheny.edu
Office Location: Alden Hall 106
Office Hours: Visit Google Calendar to reserve an appointment as needed.

title: Syllabus: CMPSC 105.00 Data Exploration, Spring 2025
text:
Course Description
An introduction to the methods of collecting, exploring, transforming and visualizing data for storytelling. Often participating in team-based and hands-on activities, students learn how to use web platforms and dashboards to acquire, explore and investigate data to generate summarized key data insights using visual techniques. Students also apply open-source programming language to discover patterns in the data, test hypotheses, and check assumptions using graphical representations. During a weekly laboratory session, students employ cutting-edge software tools to complete projects, reporting on their results through both written documents and oral presentations. Students are invited to use their own departmentally approved laptop in this course; a limited number of laptops are available for use during class and lab sessions.
Prerequisite: None
Distribution Requirements: QR, SP.
DR tag rationale: This course will primarily focus on methods of data collection, foundational data analysis of numerical data, and visualizations of such data. Additionally, students will participate in the scientific process during the exploratory data analysis and apply scientific reasoning to analyze and synthesize data.

Learning Outcomes

Develop hypotheses based on motivating problems and/or observations and identify appropriate data to address hypotheses.
Identify and describe key elements in different types of data visualizations.
Use web-based platforms to accurately present data sets through multiple visualizations.
Use an open-source programming language to compute summary statistics and visualize key patterns in the data.
Contribute to and present structured, web-based documentation that describes data exploration steps and visualization-based conclusions.



Scientific Process and Knowledge (SP)

Courses involving Scientific Process and Knowledge aim to convey an understanding of what is known or can be known about the natural world; apply scientific reasoning towards the analysis and synthesis of scientific information; and create scientifically literate citizens who can engage productively in problem solving.
Learning Outcome: Students who successfully complete this requirement will demonstrate an understanding of the nature, approaches, and domain of scientific inquiry.



Quantitative Reasoning (QR)

Quantitative Reasoning is the ability to understand, investigate, communicate, and contextualize numerical, symbolic, and graphical information towards the exploration of natural, physical, behavioral, or social phenomena.
Learning Outcome: Students who successfully complete this requirement will demonstrate an understanding of how to interpret numeric data and/or their graphical or symbolic representations.

title: Syllabus: CMPSC 105.00 Data Exploration, Spring 2025
text:
Schedule at-a-glance
Welcome

Week One: January 14, 16: Setup

Data Display

Week Two: January 21, 23: Display Types and Anatomy of a Chart
Week Three: January 28, 30: Data Distortion
Week Four: February 4, 7: Data Filtering
Week Five: February 11, 13: Interactive Display

Data Gathering

Week Six: February 18, 20: Turning Anything Into Data 
Week Seven: February 25, 27: Web Data Analytics and Scraping
Spring Break: March 1-9
Week Eight: March 11, 13: Data Entry and Storage with Pandas

Data Processing

Week Nine: March 18, 20: Statistics
Week Ten: March 25, 27: Data Transformations
Week Eleven: April 1, 3: Modeling and Overfitting
Week Twelve: April 8: Clustering

Data Storytelling

Week Thirteen: April 15, 17: Hypothesis Driven Analysis
Week Fourteen: April 22, 24: Storytelling Challenge & Project Preparation
Week Fifteen: April 29: No Class Meeting

Final Presentations Code C

Thursday, May 1st, 2025 at 7:00 PM: Final Project Lightning Talks

Complete Final Exam Schedule

title: Syllabus: CMPSC 105.00 Data Exploration, Spring 2025
text:
Grading



Assignment type
Percentage




Labs
50%


Participation
30%


Final Project
20%



Grading policy may change as needed during the term; any changes will be announced to the class at the time of the change. Grades will be communicated via Canvas. Please note that attendance policies may additionally affect grades as adjustments to grades will be applied on top of the base grade according to policy

Labs
There are 8 labs during the semester. Due dates are hard deadlines. See below for policy on late work.
The deliverables for labs include documentation in a GitHub repo addressing specific questions or demonstrating requested calculations, analyses, visualizations, and code snippets.
Labs will be graded for having clean work with few careless errors, correct Markdown, code, data, correct images given the context of the lab, and correct explanations of concepts in writing


Participation
Participation in class work, group activities, and Discord are required. Documentation of in-class participation must be submitted by each student and cannot be made up. Participation on the Discord server can occur throughout each week. Each student is required to post at least once per week by asking either asking a real question or answering a question asked by your classmate. Collegial conversations about course topics or activities are also allowed.
You will have access to a repository for submitting all of your class activities. Each activity that you do in class will contribute to your overall participation grade. There is no grading scheme for class activities. I will simply check that the activity was turned in at the end of the class period, and that you have made an effort to do the activity as intended, and figures are showing.
If the activity is not turned in at the end of the class period, then it will not be counted toward your participation grade.


Final Project
The final project will be open ended. Techniques and skills learned throughout the course should be demonstrated in the project in a final presentation (included in the final project grade). The project must be approved by the teaching team in an initial stage. The artifact can be detailed blog post, following the format of the last lab, or a detailed data visualization with interactive visuals.

title: Syllabus: CMPSC 105.00 Data Exploration, Spring 2025
text:
Policies

Attendance
Students are expected to come to class prepared, on time, and to stay engaged for the duration of the class period. This includes both class and lab sessions. This behavior is core to our shared departmental values and is in addition to the college’s attendance policy.

Preparedness
Coming to class prepared means coming with everything you need to engage in a class session. To satisfy basic expectations of CIS courses, this means, at minimum, that students must:

arrive at class with a fully charged laptop
bring their laptop charger or a battery pack so as to ensure that their laptop works throughout the entire class session
complete any pre-session work such as readings and preparatory assignments



Attendance and Lateness
One missed class or lab session counts as one absence. Coming to class/lab late, leaving early, or missing a large portion of a class/lab session will result in your being marked as “late” to class. Coming to class/lab unprepared may also result in being marked “late”. Being marked “late” to class three times during the course of a semester is equal to one absence.
Students can have five absences without any impact to their grade. These accommodations are meant to cover illness and emergency, so you should always come to class if you are able to do so.
As a general guideline, students cannot miss more than two weeks of class in total throughout the academic semester without receiving a letter grade reduction.
For this course, excluding the first week and five excused absences, overall course grade will go down by 1/3 of a letter grade for each additional absence or absence equivalence regardless of base grade.


Engagement
The term “engagement” or our expectation that students remain “engaged” can mean many things, often varying by course. Baseline behaviors that indicate engagement include:

participation in class activities and discussions
defined contribution to class sessions in full-class or group discussions
note-taking (physical or digital)
participating in course session attendance requirements
not participating in non-course related activities
not completing non-course related projects




Late Work Policy
The deadlines for assignments are hard deadlines. This policy is intended to ensure that students keep up with course topics, are able to actively participate in class, and are accountable for managing time effectively.
All students in the CIS department are expected to turn in assignments on time. “On time” means on or before the assignment’s due date. This means that an assignment cannot be turned in for credit after a due date, unless the student applies a token.

Tokens
Students in 105 are allotted four tokens to receive extensions on any assignment except the final with no questions asked by the course instructor except either in the rare cases of documented severe and/or extenuating circumstances or in cases that violate the CIS policy document or any College-approved policy.
A token may be applied via a Google Form up to the assignment deadline, with exceptions granted only for severe and/or extenuating circumstances.
Tokens grant an automatic extension of one week to anything except the final exam.
Token Form for Automatic Extension



Extenuating Circumstances
Extenuating circumstances are exceptional, unforeseen, outside of your control, and short-term, like illness and emergency. Regular circumstances associated with taking courses at Allegheny College are not considered extenuating.
The accommodations provided by tokens and permitted absences are meant to cover extenuating circumstances like illness, emergency, and work. However, if you have a contagious illness like COVID-19, the flu, or a cold, you should not come to class. If you have expended all your absences and tokens and are still sick with a contagious illness, you may contact your professor about options. If your symptoms are mild or you are recovering from a respiratory illness, we recommend that you wear a mask to class.
Professor must be informed of all athletic obligations at the beginning of the semester, or with as much notice as possible. If you are feeling healthy and well, you should make every effort to come to class on time and to complete assignments, rather than using absences and tokens you may need later.
These no-questions-asked accommodations are meant to protect student privacy, and to remove the additional effort of acquiring documentation under duress of illness or emergency. In addition, they allow the professor to remain focused on teaching rather than adjudicating excuses.
If extenuating circumstances are severe enough to require more absences and tokens, you may contact your professor to discuss options. In most cases, however, a situation of this gravity warrants a request for a “Late Drop” or “Incomplete” in the course, as the student will not have had adequate opportunity to learn the material.

title: Syllabus: CMPSC 105.00 Data Exploration, Spring 2025
text:
Communications

Using GitHub and Discord
This course will primarily use GitHub and Discord for collaborative course communication. Communications that are not private matters must take place in the Data Exploration Channel in Discord.
The Allegheny College Computer and Information Science Discord Server will also have useful announcements about departmental activities including TL office hours.


Using Email
Although we will primarily use Discord for class communication, the course instructor will sometimes use email to send announcements about important matters such as changes in the schedule. It is your responsibility to check your email at least once a day and to ensure that you can reliably send and receive emails.

title: Syllabus: CMPSC 105.00 Data Exploration, Spring 2025
text:
Honor Code
The Academic Honor Program that governs the entire academic program at Allegheny College is described in the Allegheny Academic Bulletin. The Honor Program applies to all work that is submitted for academic credit or to meet non-credit requirements for graduation at Allegheny College. This includes all work assigned for this class (e.g., examinations and course assignments). All students who have enrolled in the College will work under the Honor Program. Each student who has matriculated at the College has acknowledged the following Honor Code pledge:

I hereby recognize and pledge to fulfill my responsibilities, as defined in the Honor Code, and to maintain the integrity of both myself and the College community as a whole.


Effective Collaboration
Computer science is an inherently collaborative discipline. The Department of Computer and Information Science at Allegheny College encourages students to engage in collaboration. However, in the context of individual coursework, through which each student must demonstrate their own knowledge, there are certain forms of collaboration that are and are not acceptable.

Acceptable forms of collaboration include:

Discussing high-level concepts.
Referring someone to a course text book, course slides, example programs, or other resources that contain helpful information or instructions.
Outlining the high-level steps to solving a problem, without mentioning specific
lines of code that need to be written.

Unacceptable forms of collaboration include:

Sharing details about specific lines of code, including showing your source code to someone or looking at someone else’s code.
Copying someone else’s source code, technical writing, program commands, or program output, even with some slight modifications.
Typing source code, technical writing, or commands on someone else’s computer.




Plagiarism and Artificial Intelligence
Students may not pass off or represent the work of another student, or their own prior work, as their own current work in any case. Plagiarism and AI-generatated code, text, or images are not permitted in any assignment type unless the instructions supplied for the assignment explicitly state otherwise.For exams and all other coursework, students are expected to adhere to the given instructions for the particular exam or item of coursework. It is the responsibility of the student to review the authorization specifications on every item and act appropriately, upholding the honor code. Suspected plagiarized or unauthorized use of AI to generate the work that is turned in will be reported to the Honor Code Committee. This policy does not preclude the use of AI to learn.

title: Syllabus: CMPSC 105.00 Data Exploration, Spring 2025
text:
Educational Accommodations
The Americans with Disabilities Act (ADA) is a federal anti-discrimination statute that provides comprehensive civil rights protection for persons with disabilities. Among other things, this legislation requires all students with disabilities be guaranteed a learning environment that provides for reasonable accommodation of their disabilities. Students with disabilities who believe they may need accommodations in this class are encouraged to contact Student Accessibility and Support Services (SASS) at 814-332-2898. Student Accessibility and Support Services is part of the Learning Commons and is located in Pelletier Library. Please do this as soon as possible to ensure that approved accommodations are implemented in a timely fashion.

title: Welcome to CMPSC 105
text:
Learning Outcomes

Identify and describe key elements in different types of data visualizations.
Visualize data on web-based platforms.
Develop hypotheses and find data to address hypotheses.
Calculate statistics and visualize key patterns in the data with Python.
Document data explorations in markdown.
